title: The Return Proclaimed
shortSummary: Ezra chapter 1 records the decree of King Cyrus of Persia, inspired by God, allowing the Jewish exiles to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple. This chapter highlights God's faithfulness in fulfilling His promise through Jeremiah and the enthusiastic response of the returned exiles.
timeline: c. 538 BC - Decree of Cyrus and the beginning of the Jewish return from Babylonian exile

keyCharacters.name: Cyrus
keyCharacters.description: King of Persia who, moved by God, issues the decree permitting the Jews to return to Jerusalem and rebuild the temple.

keyCharacters.name: Sheshbazzar
keyCharacters.description: Prince of Judah appointed to oversee the return and restoration efforts, responsible for the temple vessels.

keyCharacters.name: Mithredath
keyCharacters.description: Treasurer under King Cyrus who hands over the temple vessels to Sheshbazzar.

definitions.definition: An official public announcement, often by a king or government, declaring a decree or law.

definitions.term: Vessels of the house of the LORD
definitions.definition: Sacred temple items used in worship, including gold and silver utensils, taken by Nebuchadnezzar and now returned.
Voluntary gifts given by individuals to support the work of God, beyond any required offerings.
To live temporarily in a place; referring here to Jews living outside Jerusalem who are encouraged to assist the returning exiles.

outline.heading: God Inspires Cyrus to Issue a Decree
outline.description: God stirs the heart of Cyrus to proclaim the return of the Jewish exiles to Jerusalem to rebuild the temple, fulfilling Jeremiah’s prophecy and demonstrating God's sovereign control over earthly rulers.

outline.heading: Support for the Returnees
outline.description: Cyrus commands that those who remain in their places assist the returning exiles with resources, showing communal support and generosity toward the rebuilding effort.

outline.heading: Restoration of Temple Vessels
outline.description: Cyrus orders the return of the sacred temple vessels taken by Nebuchadnezzar, which are handed over to Sheshbazzar, symbolizing the restoration of proper worship and God’s presence among His people.

application: Trust in God's sovereign plan even when circumstances seem difficult, knowing He can move the hearts of rulers to accomplish His purposes.
Be willing to support and encourage others in their God-given missions, offering resources and assistance generously.
Recognize the importance of obedience to God's commands, as seen in the eagerness of the exiles to rebuild the temple.
Celebrate and preserve the things God has entrusted to His people, including the means of worship and spiritual heritage.

keyVerses.text: Now in the first year of Cyrus king of Persia, that the word of the LORD by the mouth of Jeremiah might be fulfilled, the LORD stirred up the spirit of Cyrus king of Persia, that he made a proclamation throughout all his kingdom, and put it also in writing, saying,
keyVerses.significance: This verse shows God's sovereign hand in fulfilling prophecy and using a pagan king to accomplish His redemptive plan.

keyVerses.text: Who is there among you of all his people? his God be with him, and let him go up to Jerusalem, which is in Judah, and build the house of the LORD God of Israel, (he is the God,) which is in Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the call to action for God's people to return and rebuild the temple, emphasizing God's presence with those who obey.

keyVerses.text: Then rose up the chief of the fathers of Judah and Benjamin, and the priests, and the Levites, with all them whose spirit God had raised, to go up to build the house of the LORD which is in Jerusalem.
keyVerses.significance: This verse illustrates the willing and Spirit-empowered response of God's people to the call for restoration.
